moves.1. Nf3:
Hi everyone!

Before I hot up the action again I will calm things down a bit with a nice bit of endgame study.  There will be three games where this time Henry plays a more active part and Glenda for the most part is off the board.  To find out if I come out better in these games you will need to either read them through or read the GA version below.  I start out with the Reti Opening which seems to transpose into a French Defense.  Here is the GA version: http://gameknot.com/analyze-board.pl?bd=26752485&rnd=0.7949995190687167
moves.5. Bb5+ Nc6 6. d4: 6. d4 - pin followed by pawn thrust.
moves.9. Qf3 Bd6 10. Re1: 10. Re1 - threatening a nastie such as Nxc6+ winning the BQ on the next turn.
moves.10... O-O 11. Bxc6 bxc6 12. Nxd7 Qxd7 13: 14. Qxf4 - a plethora of exchanges has left black with doubled pawns and Glenda takes an active position on the board.
moves.14... Rfe8 15. Kf1 Rab8 16. Rxe8+ Rxe8 1: 18. Kxe1 - after another set of exchanges we are into an endgame.
moves.18... Qe8+ 19. Kd2 h6 20. h3 Qe7 21. Qb8: 21. Qb8+ Glenda steems down to b8 and puts pressure on a7.  At the moment I may need to think about giving my d4 pawn some protection.
moves.21... Kh7 22. f3 Nh5: 22. ..... Nh5 - threatening at some stage to come to f4 or even g3.
moves.23. Qh2 Qf6 24. Ne2: 24. Ne2 - defends against this threat and also the d4 pawn.
moves.24... g5 25. Qe5 Qxe5 26. dxe5: 26. dxe5 - queen trade.  Now we have our knight endgame.
moves.26... Kg6 27. g4: 27. g4 - putting the question to the h5 knight which then retreats to g7.
moves.27... Ng7 28. Nd4 c5 29. Nc6: 29. Nc6 - threatens Nxa7 and a bit more.
moves.30... Kg7 31. Nxd5 Kf8 32. c3: 32. c3 - prevents Nd4 and keeps black's queenside pawns doubled and isolated.
moves.32... Ke8 33. Ne3 Nf4 34. Nf5 Nxh3 35. N: 35. Nxh6 - pawn trade and keeping my pawn plus.
moves.35... Nf4 36. Nf5 Ng6: 36. ...... Ng6  this move threatens Nxe5 on the next turn and it seems that there is no saving the e pawn.  However, another knight fork will save it.
moves.37. Nd6+: 37. Nd6+ - on the next turn black's d4 pawn will drop off and the pawn on e5 will be protected giving me a 2 pawn lead in the endgame.  My opponent decided this deficit was far too much and waved the white flag.
